title: My cool Idea to combat toxicity :)
body:
I have a couple ideas to combat toxicity, I want to see if the community likes any of the ideas. it's Long so Thank you if you stuck around and read it all


**1: A meter bar that shows how toxic you are, It can look similar to a gas tank meter but small on the client when you log in.
**
Light Green - You are not toxic at all - If you remain at this level at the end of the Season you will receive 1 Free Mystery Skin

Dark Green - You have bad days - If you remain at this level a the end of the Season you will receive 1 Free Summoner Icon

Yellow - You are slightly toxic - You receive no EXTRA rewards but still your end of Season Rewards

Orange - You are toxic -  You get a pop up when you open the client to remember to stay positive (Idk? )

Red - You are extremely toxic and nearing your next ban phase - You get no end of Season rewards (Remains the same)


Reasons why I think this would help

1: I don't think this would promote toxicity, as that was the first issue I thought about my idea, but I think people who are toxic generally are toxic and people who aren't toxic, wouldn't suddenly become toxic just because there's that option.

2: You can add incentizes for remaining in the Light Green - Dark Green at the end of the season. You can add a Mystery Skin for Light Green summoners and a Mystery Summoner Icon for Dark Green Icon.

3: It provides clarity for Toxic players to realize they need to stop and will also provide clarity as to whether the reports against you are valid. I see alot of people saying they get report warnings for games they never spoke in, it happens to me too. This would show post game that your toxicity level never raised and provides a VISUAL feedback for people who are so inclined to know where they are standing.

4: It will promote less permabans and a generally nicer community. People will know exactly where they stand. I'm sure more people will stop toxicity all together once they reach the Red Stage in fear of actually getting banned. It can also show (to couple with my other post) how hate speeches and racism,homophobia can jump you from Tier to Tier, so it shows just how serious Riot is about these occurrences in League.


5: As someone who's been toxic and reformed, I can tell you first hand if I had something like this. I never would of made it as far as I did. The chat logs and never ending warnings that I didn't know were serious or not because I was in the heat of a two way argument was not giving me incentive to stop. However staying at that Light Green at the beginning of the season and really wanting that Mystery Gift and seeing it on a day to day basis would probably of been better in serving MY personal preference. 



Second Idea: This one is a little more controversial but funny to me

**To people who are Chat Restricted and Toxic, make it so they can't say toxic words. Not that it's beeped out but that it simply doesn't show in chat. **

I just think it would be really funny if you saw a Chat restricted person say  ____ you Teemo , Id _______ love ________ you 

I find there's some words that in general just don't belong in online gaming and there no need or way that anyone would ever need to use them constructively. This includes Racist, Homophobic, Death Threat words. So why even allow people to have to read this nonsense? Make them invisible.

Now I know the counter argument "Freedom of Speech! Freedom of Speech!" "Mute button!"

Yes I know, but I think this should only apply to Chat restricted people, where their right to talk freely has been taken away(it already is) because of their abusive nature. It would also make it so that they can't send other people on tilt because people won't have to read their sometimes hurtful words(not so much to me but i've seen people on the forums here genuinely hurt) 

It would encourage the toxic player to know, there is no fighting back against the system, you are chat restricted, anything you say that is toxic will sound like a funny mad lib and actually promote laughter and positivity to your team.


Thank you so much if you read it all. Leave comments, Replies and feedback down below!

replies.body:
So, essentially this?
 https://coffee2words.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/stitchbadness.jpg
Yes, in so many words, this.
Yes! Visualizing toxicity is genius! I love it.
This has been suggested before and the problem people always forget is that it can be used to safely maximize your toxicity.

If someone is legit trying to be an exact level of toxic, then they likely are just trying to hard. A toxic person isn't going to care, and a non-toxic person will most likely not care about it since if they're doing good they won't be effected.

> [{quoted}](name=Jari,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=gOeXfnnI,comment-id=000d0000,timestamp=2015-12-26T19:12:38.541+0000)
>
> If someone is legit trying to be an exact level of toxic, then they likely are just trying to hard. A toxic person isn't going to care, and a non-toxic person will most likely not care about it since if they're doing good they won't be effected.

Perhaps you misunderstand. Let's say that I get punished when the meter hits 10. I do a little testing and discover that I gain 0.1 - 0.2 if I'm especially toxic during a match. I also figure out that a week's worth of not being reported causes me to drop 0.5. Now I know exactly what I need to do to never be punished and punishments become useless

Given an opportunity, people will game the system.

This is exactly what I was initially thinking. You bring up a really good point. This is why I think more harsh hate speeches can immediately jump people from one level to the other. I think overall you will have to be minutely toxic to be able to game the system .5%'s at a time. Which already exists in League on a game to game basis. 

Riot suggests that they have harsher and immediate escalation in penalties for hate speeches. It would be even more beneficial to show that person. "Oh man I was really toxic that game, I went up half a bar! I need to stop"

Overall. That is the biggest issue with this concept. I still believe that non-toxic people wouldn't attempt to game the system due to their nature of not being toxic, and toxic people might look to reform more than they already are. 

In addition I would imagine Riot has a similar system in place right now, but is just rather invisible to us, and people are still learning to abuse that system. 

TLDR; Riot's system already has a similar implemented system, I believe the clarity would be more beneficial rather than the current state of unknown(everyone knows you go down a tier of punishment after 3 months of playing on a smurf or etc. doesn't mean you have reformed)

You don't want people thinking they have **any** leeway. They must believe, at all times, that being toxic puts their account at risk. 

>verall. That is the biggest issue with this concept. I still believe that non-toxic people wouldn't attempt to game the system due to their nature of not being toxic, **and toxic people might look to reform more than they already are**.

We have several years of data that shows that people who are going to reform do so at fairly consistent rates regardless of what the punishment is. They respond solely because the punishment shows them that Riot is serious. This is why the "punishment volcano" was shortened to four steps. 

Trust me, I suggested a thermometer system a long time ago.

Every toxic player i have run into has said something along the lines of "This won't get me banned anyways" because they don't fear it. So the argument while it would hopefully have people suffering from the "fear of God" doesn't actually have any effect unless they see "an act of God" (if that analogy doesn't makes sense to sum up unless they see they are being watched they don't care.)

Edit: better comparison. If a parent says "hey do this or else" and you never do it and no consequences come you won't ever do it when asked again. I do see your point but i think a meter would be awesome to remind people "hey chill" and the rewards are nice for those that chose to follow the rules.

On second thought, perhaps you're right. 

However I disagree that the majority of toxic players right now believe at all time that their accounts are at risk, maybe it's just careless disregard.. I'm sure you have more info than I do, or maybe I'm seeing more outbursts than usual, I agree on one thing though. There is less taunting about the system now than during the punishment volcano period. Simply from my perspective though. Mind you, I play a lot of games.


I always tend to forgot that Riot has a lot of people putting fourth ideas all the time.

Maybe this idea isn't the best given that when system's get abused they get abused hard.

Though after every game that I get a toxic player I do find myself asking "is there really any way to fix this?"

Thanks for the feedback. Good to have a logical constructive point of view.

One last question:  I wonder if Riot will of seen a massive increase in permabans since the implementation of their new system, I know for a fact I've seen a lot more on the boards lately...what does this tell us about our previously conceived ideas about the current state of the "toxicity" in the games? Is it really as low as we think it is?(1-2%) or is it much larger than we expected(taking into consideration smurfs dont get played on as much as mains, bot accounts, double -triple account owners) since the new system clamps down better than the old.

I strongly support the toxicity meter.  This visual warning offers much more clarity to toxic players who need to reform their behavior.  Once they know that they are close to receiving a punishment, that gives them more incentive to monitor their actions with other players in a game.

No automated system is going to be able to measure it in a meaningful way.  It would just bloat the game with yet another unnecessary and pointless system.... kinda like the current honor system.

This isn't adding any different forms of finding toxicity, it isn't adding any form of what is considered toxic or false reports it's simply VISUALIZING it for you to see how toxic you are. 

If you have a problem with automated systems and discrete measurement for toxicity. League might not be for you. There is ALREADY a system for that and they are only putting more, there always will be.

I think they only thing it would do would make people scared of engaging in an argument. Remember talking isn't toxic and would have no effect on your meter, and false reports would not change your toxic meter at all. However engaging in an argument and becoming toxic in a game might

I'm gonna have to stop you at "free mystery skin". That doesn't seem right. It's like telling an ex-con, "here, have a free 100 bucks. You didn't rob a store this month." Wait what...

Seriously, don't give people a medal just for not having anger management issues. Rewards are for results that exceed expectations. Not for things that are MANDATORY.

Should your boss hand you a cookie every morning you remember to put your pants on before coming into work? ... ... Well, actually, I could live with that.

Also... completely removing censored words? Right, because THAT will stop players from putting spaces in between the letters just so ANY form of censorship is totally bypassed anyway.

The only problem is whatever you're implying you have a problem with is already in place. They **already** give you rewards for positivity, and **ALREADY** take away rewards for bad behavior, this wouldn't change league at all just provide clarity as to where you stand. 


In addition Riot has already said most players are in the "have a bad day "category where they rage sometimes just not all the time I think the number is 76-80% Lyte said. Which makes it even more special to get into the Light Green category, So Ex-Con? More like Man of the Year.

 Your example is a complete fallacy. Why are you comparing an upstanding citizen with an Ex-Con? There is no way you can be an Ex-Con and still be in the Light Green section to receive the mystery skin a way to make sure of this is that after reaching a ban you start off 1 section higher each time.. A better example would be your boss gives you a cookie because you show Organizational Behavior of the workplace at work and exemplify a good attitude while at work.


Second one, yeah meh...but by your logic why even have any rules at all. People still find a way to break em! Why even have laws! People will break em! The idea is to make it harder for people to break it. Pretty simple concept. If someone is typing out their whole rage speech spaced out, I would personally find that pretty hilarious that they went through all the trouble to do it. RIght now you can just rage away freely.
Not to mention a mystery skin is <$5 and it's at the end of the year, not monthly, so his argument about just giving someone $100 a month to not steal your store is even more invalid. :P

When I treat people respectfully in game, I don't expect anything in return. Especially not from Riot. I just hope I've made the day a little bit better for other players. That's the thing about manners. You don't do it for yourself. You do it for other people. If you want to completely miss that point, fine. This discussion is a waste of time then.

But in case it's not, and you'll actually take something away from this, here's what I have to say about your comments.

> this wouldn't change league at all just provide clarity as to where you stand

I did not object to your "meter" idea, nor did I even comment on it. You're either digressing, or implying you need a free skin for, ahem, "clarity as to where you stand". I don't need a free skin to know when I'm not being an ass in games.

> Why are you comparing an upstanding citizen with an Ex-Con?

It's called an analogy. And in order for it to work, you scale every comparative trait up. And the comparison is not to all players, but SPECIFIC players. Players who don't treat other players like dirt by default don't need a cookie. They grew up at some point. So the only people we're talking about are the ones who have trouble acting decently in the first place. And if they cease that activity, then yes, they're REFORMED players. Ergo, Ex-Con is an appropriate analogy, provided everything else is scaled accordingly (offense, reward, penalty, etc.) Hence, $100 for not robbing a store... yet you fault me for scaling up the offense while someone else replies to you saying "it's even worse, he scaled up the reward". The lack of understanding here is astounding. You probably already realized all this, but I'll give you the benefit of the doubt that you are sincerely missing the point.

> There is no way you can be an Ex-Con and still be in the Light Green section...

Um... I didn't realize you had a meter color for "so outrageous, is probably an ex-con". Either that, or you think I'm talking about theoretically well-mannered players who are ACTUALLY ex-cons, who's existence you've denied by stereotyping ex-cons as punks... ... Whatever of the case, your paragraph gets face-palm-ingly absurd, really quickly. Which is why I actually had to say the sentence, "It's called an analogy."

> A better example would be your boss gives you a cookie because you show Organizational Behavior of the workplace at work and exemplify a good attitude while at work.

This is what you get rewarded for at work: PERFORMANCE. Quality at whatever you were hired to do, which has NOTHING to do with behavior. Here's how you get "rewarded" for behavior: No one fires you.

> The idea is to make it harder for people to break it.

Censoring with asterisks vs underscores vs spaces does not make anything harder to break.

That's the last I'll say in this thread. Respond all you like, but I won't be reading it. I put forth the time for one response out of kindness to most people, but beyond that, I don't waste time in a thread once I realize it's populated by players with hopelessly skewed reasoning.

Why would freedom of speech be an argument? It's not like that's a requirement anywhere except the areas that the constitution guarantees in the US (which is only from the government). Private property/media is completely free to censor content and in fact is generally expected to do so. If ESPN suddenly didn't think to focus on sports instead of gardening their viewers would be amazingly upset. There may be many words or phrases like "damn it" that people don't agree on whether they are an issue, or agree they should not be edited, but some language just doesn't have a use in a positive community and could easily be agreed upon by most civilized human beings that as a private company Riot would be entirely okay to code the game to not allow it.
